DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: ADCS
SetDescription: this definition set refers to the various functions an ADCS implements. It is to be used for the ADCS capability description.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: AdvisorySystemAdvice
SetDescription: this is the part associated to advices provided by advisory systems.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: ContextualData
SetDescription: This category defines the vocabulary to describe contextual data.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataDependencies
SetDescription: this definition set covers the physical dependence of a `DrillingDatPoint` on something else.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataFlow
SetDescription: this category refers to the data processing. It should probably be renamed accordingly. It should define and organize the different types of processing encountered during drilling operations. A Thursday session was devoted to those items. Note that in the current version, control flow is also included: a controller is seen as a special type of processing unit, that generates commands based on measurements and set-points. This can of course be modified if deemed necessary. Note also that transmission is included there as well. A telemetry system is seen as a processing unit that only duplicates a signal, and a delay is associated to the duplication process. While this is a useful way of looking at telemetry, it is probably not intuitive enough.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataProviders
SetDescription: description of the different actors involved in the well construction process

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataTransmission
SetDescription: this category contains all nouns and verbs used to describe the rig's telemetry, for each signal. Downhole telemetry has focus.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataValidity
SetDescription: this category contains all the nouns and verbs used to described the validity of signals. Some signals are for example only valid while off-slips, downhole signals transmitted via mud-pulse telemetry require circulation.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingDataSemantics
SetDescription: this is the part associated to the signal's description themselves. Dimensionality, data type are the main items to be described.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingEquipment
SetDescription: in this category fall all the standard equipment encountered on a drilling rig. Note that the goal of the vocabulary is not to provide a detailed description of the rig. Therefore we only consider nouns that can help providing a signal context.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingFeature
SetDescription: this definition set refers various drilling features that something may support.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingIncident
SetDescription: this category refers mostly to the description of drilling incidents.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingLimit
SetDescription: this category refers mostly to the description of drilling limits.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingObjective
SetDescription: this category refers mostly to the description of drilling objectives.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingProcedure
SetDescription: this category refers mostly to the description of drilling procedures.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DWISSemantics
SetDescription: definitions of the base noun and verb. All verbs and nouns in the DWIS vocabulary are children of those.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: EndPoints
SetDescription: this is the part associated to the description of external end-points.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Hydraulics
SetDescription: this part refers to the hydraulic circuit, and should only contain the "abstract" or conceptual part of the vocabulary. Additional nouns coming from the drilling equipment category will be used when constructing the semantic graphs.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: MechanicalModel
SetDescription: specialized vocabulary for the modelling of the drilling mechanics. Covers in particular the so-called torque and drag models

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Mechanics
SetDescription: this part refers to the mechanical circuit, and should only contain the "abstract" or conceptual part of the vocabulary. Additional nouns coming from the drilling equipment category will be used when constructing the semantic graphs.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Model
SetDescription: high level and generic vocabulary for mathematical models of the drilling process

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: PhysicalLocation
SetDescription: this category contains the vocabulary necessary to specify the location of various items on a rig. Coordinate systems are the main element here.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Quantities
SetDescription: quantities and units

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: SignalPrototypes
SetDescription: this is description set for specialization of signa prototypes.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: TimeManagement
SetDescription: this category referes mostly to the description of the various clocks that can be encoutered on a rig, and their synchronization status with respect to each other.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Uncertainty
SetDescription: this category contains the nouns and verbs required to describe the various types of uncertainty attached to drilling signals. Uncertainties can be related to sensor characteristics, calculations, model calibration, data assimilation.

Nouns.Name: ActivableFunction
Description: An `ActivableFunction` is an ADCS function that can be activated. Here activation means that the
function may run immediately or that it is enabled and can trigger if some conditions are respected.
Examples: This example describes all `ActivableFunction` provided by the drilling control system, `DCS`. The `DCS` is
defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor.

Nouns.Name: RunnableFunction

NounAttributes.Name: IsAuxiliary
Description: This attribute specifies if the function is a main or an auxilary one. A main function impacts
substantially the drilling process while an auxiliary function does not impact or only in limited fashion the
drilling process. Example of a main functions are: Hoist, Tag Bottom, Start Circulation, Start Rotation,
Stop Circulation, Stop Rotation, Drill, Pull Out,Run In, Pull Out With Lubrication, Run In With Lubrication, Ream Up,
Ream Down,Test Friction, Reciprocate, Test Pressure Integrity, Place Cement, .... Example of auxiliary functions
are: Boost Riser Flow, Down Link from ADCS, Rock Pipe, ...
A runnable function is a function that starts to run immediately when activated.
Examples: This example describes all the main runnable functions provided by the drilling control system, `DCS`. The `DCS` is
defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor.

Nouns.Name: ControllerFunction
Description: A `ControllerFunction` is a `RunnableFunction` that executes a feedback control loop to follow as closely
as possible one or several desired values. A typical example of `ControllerFunction` is the `AutoDriller`. An `AutoDriller`
follows as closely as possible, for instance, a desired `WOB`.
Examples: This example describes the auto driller provided by the drilling control system, `DCS`. The `DCS` is
defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor. It is a main function and its purpose is to `Drill`.

Nouns.Name: ProcedureFunction
Description: A `ProcedureFunction` is a `RunnableFunction` that executes a finites state automaton, i.e., a graph of
transitions between states. It should be noted that a `ProcedureFunction` may use control algorithms while being in one
state or when transiting from state to state. An example of `ProcedureFunction` is a friction test. A friction test has
at least three states: rotation off bottom, pick-up without rotation, slack-off without rotation. The transitions
between the different states may depend on the implementation. Each of those states uses a controller, one that controls
the rotational speed and one that controls the axial speed.
Examples: This example describes the friction test procedure provided by the drilling control system, `DCS`. The `DCS` is
defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor. It is a main function and its purpose is to perform a

Nouns.Name: ProtectionFunction
Description: A `ProtectionFunction` is an `ActivableFunction`. It must be activated to have an effect, but the effect
is to protect the drilling process, either by protecting the inputs to the drilling machines to avoid generating
a drilling incident, or to detect an abnormal drilling process state and react to the situation.
Examples: This example describes all the protection functions of the drilling control system, `DCS`. The `DCS` is
defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor.

Nouns.Name: FDIRFunction
Description: A `FDIRFunction` is a `ProtectionFunction` that reacts to a particular state of the drilling process. FDIR
stands for Fault Detection, Isolation and Recovery. An FDIR protects the drilling process by looking at its outputs.
When that state is detected, then an isolation procedure is run, and if successful and defined, a recovery procedure is
thereafter executed. In case of success of the recovery procedure, the drilling process is resumed. In all other cases,
the system returns in manual mode, usually using the safe mode management procedure. An example of `FDIRFunction` is an
Examples: This example describes the `packOffDetectionAndReaction` fault detection and isolation procedure of the drilling control
system for pack-off events, `DCS`. The `DCS` is defined as a `ControlSystem` provided by a drilling contractor.

Nouns.Name: SOEFunction
Description: A `SOEFunction` is a `ProtectionFunction` that limits the commands that are send to the drilling machines
to avoid generating a drilling incident. SOE stands for Safe Operating Envelope. A `SOEFunction` protects the inputs
of the drilling process. An example `SOEFunction` is a swab/surge limits protection. This function limits the axial acceleration
and speed of the drill-stem to avoid generate swabbing pressure below the maximum of the collapse and pore pressure, and
surging pressure above the fracturing pressure.
Examples: This example describes the `swabSurgeLimits` safe operating envelope limits to avoid detrimental swab/surge pressures in
the open hole section of the borehole.

Nouns.Name: AdvisorySystemAdvice
Description: An advisory system provides one or several advices. These advices are structured data that are stored as a JSon

Nouns.Name: DigitalTwinAdvice
Description: A digital twin simulates the drilling operation using the boundary conditions applied to the drilling system.
It provides information about the plausible values that can be expected anywhere along the drilling system. These results

Nouns.Name: DrillingStandardProcedureAdvice
Description: A drilling standard procedure advisor provides parameters for a standard procedure like starting the mud pumps or
Examples: The circulation startup procedure defines how to start the mud pumps in order to fill the pipes, break circulation and
establish a suitable flowrate in the drill-stem.
The circulation stop procedure defines how to stop the mud pumps in a way that limit potential bull-heading effects
that could result in undesired downhole pressure conditions with regards to the geo-pressure window.
The rotation startup procedure controls the steps to start the rotation of the drill-stem to reach a target rotational
speed while attempting to avoid having too large torsional oscillations.
The rotation stop procedure controls the path for stopping the rotation of the drill-stem and remove as much torque
The hoist procedure is used to move the top of the drill-stem from one elevation to another elevation while minimizing
the side effects of swab and surge.
The tag bottom procedure is used to tag the bottom hole and establish the drilling parameters.
The reciprocation procedure is used to ream up and down with the same stand. The main purpose is often to clean the hole
while avoiding to wash out the formation.
A friction test procedure is used to measure the free rotating weight and torque and the pick-up and slack-off weights.
The slow circulation rate procedure is used to measure the pressure losses of the drilling system in conditions close
to what would be necessary while circulating out a kick.
The pressure integrity test procedure is used to either check that the formation can hold the maximum expected downhole
pressure (formation integrity test) or to test the strength of the formation and the minimum horizontal stress (leak-off test and
The flow-check procedure is used to check the well is stable (no influx of formation fluids) while ensuring that the
drill-stem will not get stuck during the test.
The cementing procedure is used to displace the correct amount of cement at the right position while cleaning the borehole
to ensure good conditions for the cement setting.
The downlinking procedure is used to manipulate the flowrate/pressure or rotational speed to send a coded message to
The toolface orientation procedure is used to manipulate the top of string angular position to ensure that the downhole
motor toolface is set to a desired set-point.

Nouns.Name: DrillingControlAdvice
Description: A drilling control advisor provides information on how to control a part of the drilling process to stay as close
as possible to one or several desired values.
Examples: A ROP management controller adjusts the parameters of the auto-driller to manage the ROP. The ROP management may concern
potential problems with drill-string buckling, passing the bit founder point, vibration and cuttings transport.
When using a downhole motor for directional drilling, pipe rocking is used to assist with weight transmission during
A stick-slip mitigation controller attempts at damping stick-slip oscillations by controlling the drill-string rotation

Nouns.Name: DrillingSafeOperatingEnvelopeAdvice
Description: A safe operating envelope (SOE) advisor provides information on the limits that shall be used when controlling the drilling
process to avoid possible drilling incidents.
Examples: The min-max axial velocity SOE is used to limit the axial drill-strem velocity to avoid generating swab and surge
pressures that exceeds the geo-pressure window.
The min-max flowrate SOE is used to limit the flowrate in order to stay below the fracturing pressure limit of the open
hole formation and have a sufficient flowrate to transport cuttings to the surface.
The min-max rotational speed SOE limits the drill-stem rotational speed to avoid unwanted drill-stem vibrations while at
the same time be sufficient to facilitate cuttings transport.

Nouns.Name: DrillingFaultDetectionIsolationAndRecoveryAdvice
Nouns.DisplayName: Drilling Fault Detection Isolation and Recovery Advice
Description: A fault detection, isolation and recovery (FDIR) advisor provides information on how to detect an drilling incident
and parameters to procedure that is executed when a drilling incident is detected in order to first to isolate the drilling incident
and then possibly recover from that incident.
Examples: A pack-off FDIR function detects an abornormal dowhole pressure and executes a procedure to avoid fracturing the
open hole formation and possibly continues with a procedure to remediate the cause of the pack-off and return to normal conditions.
An overpull/underpull function detects an abnormal hook-load either while moving upward (overpull) or downward (underpull).
It reacts to the situation by stopping the axial movement and possibly starts other actions to remediate for the cause of the abnormal
hook-load with the objective to return to normal conditions.
This is the same as for an OverpullUnderpullFDIRAdvice but only deals with overpulls.
This is the same as for an OverpullUnderpullFDIRAdvice but only deals with underpulls.
An overtorque FDIR function reacts to abnormal torque conditions. The rotation is stopped and possibly counter measures
are applied to remediate the cause of the overtorque with the objective to return to normal conditions.
A gain-loss FDIR reacts to influx of formation fluids in the borehole or losses of drilling fluids to the formation.
After detection, procedures may be applied to control the gain or loss situation.
It is similar to the gain-loss FDIR advice but only focuses on a kick situation.
It is similar to the gain-loss FDIR advice but only focuses on a loss circulation situation.
A hole collapse FDIR detects whether a formation collapse is occurring. Possibly counter measures are applied to contain
the side effects of the hole collapse.
A pipe washout FDIR reacts to a situation during which a leak between the drill-string and the annulus is detected. Possible
remedial actions may be applied to limit the side effects of the pipe washout.
A twist-off FDIR reacts to the case of the undesired separation of part of the drill-stem. Possibly, a procedure may
be applied to remediate the parting of the drill-stem, like trying to reconnect if the cause of the separation was a back-off at the
A motor stall FDIR detects when a downhole motor stalls. A procedure is applied to regain rotation of the rotor of the
A whirl FDIR reacts to situation during which there is possibly harming whirling along the drill-stem. Counter-measures
may be applied to stop the whirling and return to normal conditions.
A differential sticking FDIR detects when the drill-stem is differentially stuck. It possibly applies counter-measures

Nouns.Name: ContextualData
Description: Contextual data are structured objects stored in a JSon string.

Nouns.Name: Plan
Description: A plan is a description of the actions that shall be undertaken to reach an objective

Nouns.Name: OperationalPlan
Description: An operational plan is the day-to-day list of activities that shall be performed to contruct a well.

Nouns.Name: DrillingProgram
Description: A drilling program is a set of procedures that are necessary to construct a well.

Nouns.Name: RigActionPlan
Description: A rig action plan is a set of steps and rules that shall be conducted to fulfil a particulat activity when constructing a well.

Nouns.Name: ConfigurationData
Description: Configuration data is used to configure a computation unit.

Nouns.Name: OperationalStep
Description: An operation step is a possible element of a rig action plan.

Nouns.Name: PhaseStep
Description: A phase step is at the first level of a rig action plan.

Nouns.Name: ActionStep
Description: An action step is at the second level of a rig action plan.

Nouns.Name: TaskStep
Description: A task step is at the third level of a rig action plan.

Nouns.Name: Context
Description: A context is at the fourth level of a rig action plan.
Examples: ``` dwis rigActionPlan_0 phaseStep_0 actionStep_0 taskStep_0 context_0

Nouns.Name: TrajectoryDescription
Description: A trajectory contains information about the position of the wellbore.

Nouns.Name: FluidDescription
Description: Drilling fluid contains information about the density, rheological behavior, thermo-physical and chemical characteristics of a fluid

Nouns.Name: DrillingFluidDescription
Description: A drilling fluid is a fluid that is used well

Nouns.Name: CementFluidDescription
Description: Cement fluid contains information about the density, rheological behavior and chemical characteristics of fluids
used during a cementing operation, e.g., cement slurry but also spacer.

Nouns.Name: CompletionFluidDescription
Description: Completion fluid contains information about the density, rheological behavior and chemical characteristics of a
fluid used during a completion operation.

Nouns.Name: WellboreArchitectureDescription
Description: The wellbore architecture provides information about the casings and liners in place as well as the current
open hole configuration. Also the surface architecture, i.e., everything above the wellhead, is also described, e.g., BOP, high
pressure riser, low pressure riser, expansion joint,...

Nouns.Name: DrillStemDescription
Description: A dill-stem is a generic term for all strings that are run in a borehole. The drill-stem describes the geometrical
and mechanical characteristics of such a string.

Nouns.Name: DrillStringDescription
Description: A drill-string is a drill-stem that is used during a drilling operation. It is composed of drill-pipes, drill-collars,
BHA elements and is terminated either by a bit, a bull-nose, or other special elements such as fishing equipment, etc.

Nouns.Name: CasingStringDescription
Description: A casing string is a drill-stem that is used to complete a section. It is composed of casing joints and a shoe track.

Nouns.Name: LinerStringDescription
Description: A liner string is a drill-stem that is used to complete a section. It is composed of casing joints, possibly a shoe track

Nouns.Name: ProductionStringDescription
Description: A production string is a drill-stem that is used to complete a wellbore. It is composed of tubings, expansion joints,

Nouns.Name: GeoPressuresDescription
Description: The geo-pressure data structure describes the pore pressure, collapse pressure, min horizontal stress, fracturing pressure

Nouns.Name: GeoThermalDescription
Description: The geothermal data structure describes the temperature and thermophysical properties of the formation encountered

Nouns.Name: FormationStrengthDescription
Description: The formation strength data structure describes the formation strength and internal friction angle of the formation

Nouns.Name: StratigraphyDescription
Description: The stratigraphy data structure describes the type of rock, the porosity, permeability and fluid saturations
of the formation layers that are encountered along the wellbore.

Nouns.Name: RigDescription
Description: The rig data structure describes the characteristics of the drilling equipment and any additional equipment
associated with non-standard drilling methods, e.g., back-pressure MPD, dual-gradient,...

Nouns.Name: WellBoreDataCharateristic
Description: This Noun is used to characterize a piece of wellbore data.

Nouns.Name: Planned
Description: Planned characterizes that the wellbore data is described in its planned stage. This applies to wellbore data
that is intended to be constructed.

Nouns.Name: Prognosed
Description: Prognosed characterizes that the wellbore data is described in its prognosed stage. This applies to wellbore
data that exists from before but that may be associated with uncertainty like the geology.

Nouns.Name: Measured
Description: Measured characterizes that the wellbore data has been measured or observed.

Nouns.Name: Current
Description: Current characterizes that the wellbore data is the currently selected one as the official one.

Nouns.Name: Extrapolated
Description: Extrapolated characterizes that the wellbore data is being partially measured/observed and also extended to
positions that have not been measured/observed yet.

Nouns.Name: DataFlowNode
Description: A data flow node is a generic term for any node in the data flow graph.

Nouns.Name: ComputedState
Description: A state represents the current configuation of a system.

Nouns.Name: ComputationUnit
Description: Denotes a complex computation unit, typically based on advanced numerical modeling

Nouns.Name: Advisor
Description: An advisor is a computation unit that produces an advice on how to control a process. Its output is typically

Nouns.Name: Simulator
Description: A simulator is a computation unit that tries to replicate the outputs of a process. Its output is typically
a set of ComputedData, i.e., a specialisation of DrillingDataPoint.

Nouns.Name: Interpreter
Description: An interpreter is a computation unit that interprets the state of a process. Its output is typically a

Nouns.Name: Transformation
Description: Represents a transformation applied to some signals that produces other signals

Nouns.Name: DirectTransformation
Description: Direct transformations are performed using only the current value of their inputs, time is not involved

Nouns.Name: MeasuredDepthToTrueVerticalDepthTransformation
Nouns.DisplayName: Measured Depth To True Vertical Depth Transformation

Nouns.Name: SignalProcessingUnit
Description: Represent any signal processing applied prior to the distribution of the considered signal. Signal processing refers to e.g. noise removal, filtering,..

Nouns.Name: TimeBasedTransformation
Description: Transformations that apply only to time series: time derivations, time integration, averaging...

Nouns.Name: DataProvider
Description: A data provider is any sources for data.

Nouns.Name: OperatingCompany
Description: An operating company is an entity that holds the rights to explore, develop, and produce hydrocarbon resources from a particular oil or gas field or lease

Nouns.Name: ServiceCompany
Description: A service company is an entity that provides services during the well construction.

Nouns.Name: DirectionalServiceCompany
Description: A directional service company is an entity that provides services for downhole directional drilling and downhole measurements.

Nouns.Name: DrillingFluidProvider
Description: A drilling fluid provider is a company that provides and maintains the drilling fluids during well construction.

Nouns.Name: LoggingServiceCompany
Description: A logging service company is an entity that gathers measured information during well construction.

Nouns.Name: DataAnalysisServiceCompany
Description: A data analysis service company is an entity that analyses measured data and provide new information from these measurements.

Nouns.Name: DWISInternalService
Description: A DWIS internal service is an internal component of the DWIS infrastructure that generates information that can be used by any systems connected to the DWIS infrastructure.

Nouns.Name: Telemetry

NounAttributes.Name: NumberOfRepeaters
Description: The number of repeaters between the source of the signal and the receiver.

NounAttributes.Name: DistanceBetweenRepeaters
Description: The average distance between two repeaters. The physical quantity is Length and the unit is metre.

NounAttributes.Name: AverageDelayByRepeater
Description: The average delay caused by each repeater. The physical quantity is Time and the unit is second.
Technology used for transferring the data from its main origin.

Nouns.Name: DownHoleTelemetry
Description: Technology that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface.

Nouns.Name: MudPulseTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via pressure pulses sent through the drilling fluid.

Nouns.Name: ElectromagneticTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via electromagnetic waves sent through the drilling formation.

Nouns.Name: AcousticTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via acoustic waves along the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: WiredPipeTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via electrical connections along the drill string.

Nouns.Name: InductionCouplingDownholeTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via induction coupling between pipes along the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: ElectromagneticCouplingDownholeTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via electromagnetic coupling between pipes along the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: GalvanicCouplingDownholeTelemetry
Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via galvanic coupling between pipes along the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: TopSideTelemetry
Description: Method that allows transfer of data from surface systems.

Nouns.Name: DataType
Description: Characterizes the type of data that is stored in a signal.

Nouns.Name: ContinuousDataType
Description: Specifies that the data is continuous.

Nouns.Name: DateDataType
Description: Indicates that the data is a date.

Nouns.Name: ElapsedTimeDataType
Description: Indicates that the data is an elapsed time.

Nouns.Name: NormalizedDataType
Description: Indicates that the data has been normalized and stays between 0 and 1

Nouns.Name: DiscreteDataType
Description: Specifies that the data is discrete.

Nouns.Name: EnumerationDataType
Description: Indicates that the data is an enumeration.

Nouns.Name: BooleanDataType
Description: Indicates that the data is a boolean.

Nouns.Name: StringDataType
Description: Specifies that the data is a string.

Nouns.Name: JSonDataType
Description: Specifies that the data is a string that contain the serialization in Json of an object.

Nouns.Name: DrillingDataPoint
Description: Main type of DDHub data. Represents a drilling signal.
Can be a dynamic signal (linked to a ValueNode) or a static parameter.

Nouns.Name: ProcessFeature
Description: This Noun is used for signals that describe a process feature, typically assuming that this is a static signal.

Nouns.Name: Measurement
Description: The noun Measurement represents individuals that are measured by some instrument and which value can be compared with another measurement.

Nouns.Name: DrillingSignal
Description: Data structure used to store the streaming drilling data.

NounAttributes.Name: TimeStampAtSource
Description: this is a UTC date-time value corresponding to the time at which the value has been taken.

NounAttributes.Name: TimeStampAcquisition
Description: this is a UTC date-time value at which the value has been acquired by the data acquisition system.

Nouns.Name: Feature
Description: A feature is a characteristic of something.

Nouns.Name: DataTransmissionFeature
Description: A data transmission feature is a characteristic about how data is transferred from one place to another.

Nouns.Name: LookupTableFeature
Description: Such a feature indicates that something accounts for lookup table.

Nouns.Name: DrillingManagementFeature
Description: A drilling management feature is a drilling management characteristic that is supported by something. For instance
an advisory system may provide ROP management parameters accounting for cuttings transport.

Nouns.Name: FillPipeFeature
Description: A fill pipe feature indicates that something accounts for filling the pipe when there is an air gap.

Nouns.Name: GelBreakingFeature
Description: A gel breaking feature indicates that something accounts for breaking the gel in a drilling fluid that has stayed

Nouns.Name: CirculationFeature
Description: A circulation feature indicates that something accounts for circulation.

Nouns.Name: DrillingFluidDisplacementFeature
Description: A drilling fluid displacement feature indicates that something accounts for displacing a drilling fluid with another.

Nouns.Name: DrillingFluidSweepFeature
Description: A drilling fluid sweep feature indicates that something accounts for sweeping the borehole with one or several fluids of

Nouns.Name: CementingFeature
Description: A cementing feature indicates that something accounts for displacing a train of drilling fluids and cement slurries to perform

Nouns.Name: FormationWashoutFeature
Description: A formation washout feature indicates that something accounts for formation washout while circulating.

Nouns.Name: CuttingsTransportFeature
Description: A cuttings transport feature indicates that something accounts for cuttings transport while circulating.

Nouns.Name: PackOffFeature
Description: A pack-off feature indicates that something accounts for the possibility to pack-off while circulating cuttings.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemMovementFeature
Description: A drill-stem movement feature indicates that something accounts for the drill-stem movement.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemAxialMovementFeature
Description: A drill-stem axial movement feature indicates that something accounts for drill-stem axial movement.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemRotationalMovementFeature
Description: A drill-stem rotational movement feature indicates that something accounts for drill-stem rotational movement.

Nouns.Name: StuckPipeFeature
Description: A stuck-pipe feature indicates that something accounts for stuck-pipes.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemAxialImpedimentFeature
Description: A drill-stem axial impediment feature indicates that something accounts for drill-stem axial impediment.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemRotationalImpedimentFeature
Description: A drill-stem rotational impediment feature indicates that something accounts for drill-stem rotational impediment.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemVibrationFeature
Description: A drill-stem vibration feature indicates that something accounts for drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemAxialVibrationFeature
Description: A drill-stem axial vibration feature indicates that something accounts for in particular axial drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemAxialStickSlipFeature
Description: A drill-stem axial stick-slip feature indicates that something acconts for in particular axial stick-slip drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemTorsionalVibrationFeature
Description: A drill-stem torsional vibration feature indicates that something acconts for in particular torsional drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemTorsionalStickSlipFeature
Description: A drill-stem torsional stick-slip feature indicates that something acconts for in particular torsional stick-slip drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemLateralVibrationFeature
Description: A drill-stem lateral vibration feature indicates that something accounts for in particular lateral drill-stem vibrations.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemWhirlingFeature
Description: A drill-stem whirling feature indicates that something accounts for in particular drill-stem whirling.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemForwardWhirlingFeature
Description: A drill-stem forward whirling feature indicates that something accounts for in particular drill-stem forward whirling.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemBackwardWhirlingFeature
Description: A drill-stem backward whirling feature indicates that something accounts for in particular drill-stem backward whirling.

Nouns.Name: DrillStemChaoticWhirlingFeature
Description: A drill-stem chaotic whirling feature indicates that something accounts for in particular drill-stem chaotic whirling.

Nouns.Name: DownholePressureFeature
Description: A downhole pressure feature indicates that something accounts for downhole pressure.

Nouns.Name: SwabSurgeFeature
Description: A swab and surge feature indicates that something accounts for swab and surge pressure variations.

Nouns.Name: ManagedDownholePressureFeature
Description: A managed downhole pressure feature indicates that something manages downhole pressure.

Nouns.Name: UnderBalanceFeature
Description: An under-balance feature indicates that something accounts for under-balance conditions.

Nouns.Name: GasAbsorptionFeature
Description: A gas absorption feature indicates that something accounts for conditions by which gas can be absorbed by the drilling fluid.

Nouns.Name: FormationFracturingFeature
Description: A formation fracturing feature indicates that something accounts for formation fracturing limits.

Nouns.Name: FormationCollapseFeature

Nouns.Name: UnderReamingFeature

Nouns.Name: DrillStemBucklingFeature

Nouns.Name: AbnormalOscillation
Description: This Noun represents abnormal oscillations along the drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: AbnormalAxialOscillation
Description: This Noun is used to refer to abnormal axial oscillations.

Nouns.Name: AbnormalTorsionalOscillation
Description: This Noun is used to refer to abnormal torsional oscillations.

Nouns.Name: AbnormalLateralOscillation
Description: This Noun is used to refer to abnormal lateral oscillations.

Nouns.Name: StickSlip
Description: This Noun is used to refer to stick-slips.

Nouns.Name: HFTO
Description: This Noun is used to refer to high frequency torsional oscillations.

Nouns.Name: Whirling
Description: This Noun is used to refer to abnormal lateral oscillations.

Nouns.Name: ForwardWhirl
Description: This Noun is used to refer to forward whirl.

Nouns.Name: BackwardWhirl
Description: This Noun is used to refer to backward whirl.

Nouns.Name: ChaoticWhirl
Description: This Noun is used to refer to chaotic whirl.

Nouns.Name: Shock
Description: This Noun is used to refer to lateral shocks.

Nouns.Name: TwistOff
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a twist-off situation.

Nouns.Name: Overpull
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the drill-stem hangs in something in the upward direction.

Nouns.Name: Underpull
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the drill-stem hangs in something in the downward direction.

Nouns.Name: Influx
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which there is an influx of formation fluids in the borehole.

Nouns.Name: LossCirculation
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which drilling fluid is lost to the formation.

Nouns.Name: HoleCollapse
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which there is a hole collapse.

Nouns.Name: StuckPipe
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the drill-stem is impeded to move either axially or rotationally or both.

Nouns.Name: DifferentiallyStuck
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the drill-stem is stuck because of differential sticking.

Nouns.Name: PipeWashout
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which there is leak between the inside of the drill-stem and the annulus.

Nouns.Name: FormationWashout
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the formation is being washed out.

Nouns.Name: OverTorque
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the rotation of the drill-stem is impeded.

Nouns.Name: Plugged
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the hydraulic flow-path is partially or fully blocked.

Nouns.Name: PackOff
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the annulus hydraulic flow-path is partially or fully blocked.

Nouns.Name: MotorStall
Description: This Noun is used to refer to a situation during which the downhole motor is stalled.

Nouns.Name: DrillingLimit

Nouns.Name: StableRotationalVelocityObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable rotational velocity.

Nouns.Name: StablePressureObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable pressure.

Nouns.Name: StableTorqueObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable torque.

Nouns.Name: StableDrillingObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable torque.

Nouns.Name: StableFlowrateObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable torque.

Nouns.Name: StableAxialForceObjective
Description: This Noun is used to refer to the objective of obtaining stable axial force.

Nouns.Name: WeightTransferObjective

Nouns.Name: DrillingProcedure
Description: This is the parent class for drilling procedures.

Nouns.Name: CirculationStartupProcedure
Description: The circulation stop procedure defines how to stop the mud pumps in a way that limit potential bull-heading effects
that could result in undesired downhole pressure conditions with regards to the geo-pressure window.

Nouns.Name: CirculationStopProcedure
Description: The rotation startup procedure controls the steps to start the rotation of the drill-stem to reach a target rotational
speed while attempting to avoid having too large torsional oscillations.

Nouns.Name: RotationStartupProcedure
Description: The rotation startup procedure controls the steps to start the rotation of the drill-stem to reach a target rotational
speed while attempting to avoid having too large torsional oscillations.

Nouns.Name: RotationStopProcedure
Description: The rotation stop procedure controls the path for stopping the rotation of the drill-stem and remove as much torque

Nouns.Name: HoistProcedure
Description: The hoist procedure is used to move the top of the drill-stem from one elevation to another elevation while minimizing
the side effects of swab and surge.

Nouns.Name: TagBottomProcedure
Description: The tag bottom procedure is used to tag the bottom hole and establish the drilling parameters.

Nouns.Name: PickOffBottomProcedure
Description: The pick off bottom procedure is used to pick off bottom when the bit is on bottom.

Nouns.Name: ReciprocationProcedure
Description: The reciprocation procedure is used to ream up and down with the same stand. The main purpose is often to clean the hole
while avoiding to wash out the formation.

Nouns.Name: FrictionTestProcedure
Description: A friction test procedure is used to measure the free rotating weight and torque and the pick-up and slack-off weights.

Nouns.Name: SlowCirculationRateProcedure
Description: The slow circulation rate procedure is used to measure the pressure losses of the drilling system in conditions close
to what would be necessary while circulating out a kick.

Nouns.Name: PressureIntegrityTestProcedure
Description: The pressure integrity test procedure is used to either check that the formation can hold the maximum expected downhole
pressure (formation integrity test) or to test the strength of the formation and the minimum horizontal stress (leak-off test and

Nouns.Name: FlowCheckProcedure
Description: The flow-check procedure is used to check the well is stable (no influx of formation fluids) while ensuring that the
drill-stem will not get stuck during the test.

Nouns.Name: CementingProcedure
Description: The cementing procedure is used to displace the correct amount of cement at the right position while cleaning the borehole
to ensure good conditions for the cement setting.

Nouns.Name: DownlinkingProcedure
Description: The downlinking procedure is used to manipulate the flowrate/pressure or rotational speed to send a coded message to

Nouns.Name: ToolfaceOrientationProcedure
Description: The toolface orientation procedure is used to manipulate the top of string angular position to ensure that the downhole
motor toolface is set to a desired set-point.

The meaningful precision of interfacial tension in the drilling context is typically: 0.0001 N/m

Nouns.Name: IsobaricSpecificHeatCapacityDrillingQuantity
Description: Isobaric specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one unit mass of a substance by one unit of temperature at constant pressure. It indicates how much heat energy a material can store.
The dimension of specific heat capacity is:
The SI unit for **isobaric specific heat capacity** is: joule per kilogram kelvin with the associated unit label $\frac{J}{kg \cdot K}$
The meaningful precision of specific heat capacity in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 J/kg•K

Nouns.Name: IsobaricSpecificHeatCapacityGradientPerTemperatureDrillingQuantity
Description: An isobaric specific heat capacity gradient per temperature is the first derivative of an isobaric specific heat capacity compared to temperature: $\frac{dC_p}{dT}$, where $C_p$ is a isobaric specific heat capacity and $T$ is a temperature.
The dimension of specific heat capacity gradient per temperature is:
The SI unit for **isobaric specific heat capacity gradient per temperature** is: joule per kilogram squared kelvin with the associated unit label $\frac{J}{kg \cdot K^{2}}$
The meaningful precision of isobaric specific heat capacity gradient per temperature in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 J/kg•K²

Nouns.Name: MassDensityDrillingQuantity
Description: Mass density is the amount of mass per unit volume of a substance.
The dimension of mass density is:
The SI unit for **mass density** is: kilogram per cubic metre with the associated unit label $\frac{kg}{m^{3}}$
The meaningful precision of mass density in the drilling context is typically: 1 kg/m³

Nouns.Name: MassDensityGradientPerLengthDrillingQuantity
Description: A mass density gradient per length is the first derivative of a mass density compared to a distance: $\frac{d\rho}{ds}$, where $\rho$ is the mass density and $s$ is a distance.
The dimension of mass density gradient per length is:
The SI unit for **mass density gradient per length** is: kilogram per cubic metre per metre with the associated unit label $\frac{\frac{kg}{m^{3}}}{m}$
The meaningful precision of mass density gradient per length in the drilling context is typically: 0.001 kg/m³/m

Nouns.Name: MassDensityGradientPerTemperatureDrillingQuantity
Description: A mass density gradient per temperature is the first derivative of a mass density compared to temperature: $\frac{d\rho}{dT}$, where $\rho$ is a mass density and $T$ is temperature.
The dimension of mass density gradient per temperature is:
The SI unit for **mass density gradient per temperature** is: kilogram per cubic metre per kelvin with the associated unit label $\frac{\frac{kg}{m^{3}}}{K}$
The meaningful precision of mass density gradient per temperature in the drilling context is typically: 0.001 kg/m³/K

Nouns.Name: MassDensityRateOfChangeDrillingQuantity
Description: A mass density rate of change is the time derivative of a mass density: $\frac{d\rho}{dt}$, where $\rho$ is the mass density and $t$ is time.
The dimension of mass density rate of change is:
The SI unit for **mass density rate of change** is: kilogram per cubic metre per second with the associated unit label $\frac{\frac{kg}{m^{3}}}{s}$
The meaningful precision of mass density rate of change in the drilling context is typically: 0.001 kg/m³/s

Nouns.Name: MassDrillingQuantity
Description: Mass can be experimentally defined as a measure of the body's inertia, meaning the resistance to acceleration (change of velocity) when a net force is applied. The object's mass also determines the strength of its gravitational attraction to other bodies.
The SI unit for **mass** is: kilogram with the associated unit label $kg$
The meaningful precision of mass density in the drilling context is typically: 0.1 kg

Nouns.Name: MassGradientPerLengthDrillingQuantity
Description: A mass gradient per length is the first derivative of a mass compared to a distance: $\frac{dm}{ds}$, where $m$ is a mass and $s$ is a distance.
The dimension of mass gradient per length is:
The SI unit for **mass gradient per length** is: kilogram per metre with the associated unit label $\frac{kg}{m}$
The meaningful precision of mass gradient per length in the drilling context is typically: 0.05 kg/m

Nouns.Name: MassRateDrillingQuantity
Description: A mass rate is the time derivative of a mass: $\frac{dm}{dt}$, where $m$ is a mass and $t$ is time.
The dimension of mass rate is:
The SI unit for **mass rate** is: kilogram per second with the associated unit label $\frac{kg}{s}$
The meaningful precision of mass rate in the drilling context is typically: 0.0001 kg/s

Nouns.Name: NozzleDiameterDrillingQuantity
Description: Length is a measure of distance.
The SI unit for **length** is: metre with the associated unit label $m$
The meaningful precision of small length is typically: 0.0001 m
The meaningful precision of nozzle diameter in the drilling context is typically: 0.0001 m

Nouns.Name: PlaneAngleDrillingQuantity
Description: A plane angle is the angle formed between two intersecting lines or planes in a two-dimensional or three-dimensional space.
The dimension of plane angle is:
The SI unit for **plane angle** is: radian with the associated unit label $rad$
The meaningful precision of plane angle in the drilling context is typically: 0.00017453292519943296 rad

Nouns.Name: PorousMediumPermeabilityDrillingQuantity
Description: The permeability is a property of porous medium that quantifies its ability to allow fluids to pass through it.
The dimension of porous medium permeability is:
The SI unit for **porous medium permeability** is: square metre with the associated unit label $m^{2}$
The meaningful precision of permeability in the drilling context is typically: 1E-10 m²

Nouns.Name: PositionDrillingQuantity
Description: Length is a measure of distance.
The SI unit for **length** is: metre with the associated unit label $m$
The meaningful precision of position in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 m

Nouns.Name: PowerDrillingQuantity
Description: Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred over time.
The SI unit for **power** is: watt with the associated unit label $W$
The meaningful precision of power in the drilling context is typically: 0.1 W

Nouns.Name: PressureDrillingQuantity
Description: Pressure is the force applied per unit area on a surface.
The SI unit for **pressure** is: pascal with the associated unit label $Pa$
The meaningful precision of pressure in the drilling context is typically: 10000 Pa

Nouns.Name: PressureGradientPerLengthDrillingQuantity
Description: A pressure gradient per length is the first derivative of a pressure compared to a distance: $\frac{dp}{ds}$, where $p$ is a pressure and $s$ is a distance.
The dimension of pressure gradient per length is:
The SI unit for **pressure gradient per length** is: pascal per metre with the associated unit label $\frac{Pa}{m}$
The meaningful precision of pressure gradient per length in the drilling context is typically: 10000 Pa/m

Nouns.Name: PressureLossConstantDrillingQuantity
Description: The pressure loss constant is a parameter used to quantify the resistance to flow in a system, such as a pipe or more complex tubulars, which leads to a reduction in pressure. It helps in calculating the pressure drop due to friction or other factors in fluid dynamics.
The dimension of pressure loss constant is:
The SI unit for **pressure loss constant** is: pressure loss constant SI with the associated unit label $(\frac{m^{3}}{s})^{2} \cdot \frac{(\frac{kg}{m^{3}})}{Pa}$
The meaningful precision of pressure loss constant in the drilling context is typically: 0.1 (m³/s)²•(kg/m³)/Pa

Nouns.Name: PressureRateOfChangeDrillingQuantity
Description: A pressure rate of change is the time derivative of a pressure.
The dimension of pressure rate of change is:
The SI unit for **pressure rate of change** is: pascal per second with the associated unit label $\frac{Pa}{s}$
The meaningful precision of pressure rate of change in the drilling context is typically: 10000 Pa/s

Nouns.Name: RandomWalkDrillingQuantity
Description: A random walk is a mathematical concept describing a path consisting of a series of random steps or movements, where each step's direction or magnitude is determined probabilistically. It is used to model various phenomena in fields like physics, finance, and computer science.
The dimension of random walk is:
The SI unit for **random walk** is: radian per square root second with the associated unit label $\frac{rad}{\sqrt{s}}$
The meaningful precision of random walk in the drilling context is typically: 1E-05 rad/√s

Nouns.Name: RateOfPenetrationDrillingQuantity
Description: A velocity is the time derivative of a position or a displacement: $\frac{dx}{dt}$, where $x$ is a position and $t$ is time.
The SI unit for **velocity** is: metre per second with the associated unit label $\frac{m}{s}$
The meaningful precision of rate of penetration in the drilling context is typically: 2.77778E-05 m/min

Nouns.Name: ReciprocalLengthSurveyInstrumentDrillingQuantity
Description: A wave number is the number of wave lengths per unit distance.
The dimension of wave number is:
The SI unit for **wave number** is: reciprocal metre with the associated unit label $\frac{1}{m}$
The meaningful precision of reciprocal length related to survey instrument performance models in the drilling context is typically: 1E-08 1/m

Nouns.Name: RotationalFrequencyRateOfChangeDrillingQuantity
Description: A frequency rate of change is the time derivative of a frequency: $\frac{df}{dt}$, where $f$ is a frequency and $t$ is time.
The dimension of frequency rate of change is:
The SI unit for **frequency rate of change** is: hertz per second with the associated unit label $\frac{Hz}{s}$
A rotation frequency rate of change is the time derivative of a rotation frequency.
The meaningful precision of rotational frequency is typically: 0.016666666666666666 Hz/s
The meaningful precision of rotational frequency rate of change in the drilling context is typically: 0.016666666666666666 Hz/s

Nouns.Name: StickDurationDrillingQuantity
Description: Time is a continuous, measurable progression in which events occur, from the past through the present to the future.
The SI unit for **time** is: second with the associated unit label $s$
The meaningful precision of stick duration in the drilling context is typically: 0.001 s

Nouns.Name: SurfacePoreDrillingQuantity
Description: Area is the measure of the extent of a surface or the size of a two-dimensional shape.
The SI unit for **area** is: square metre with the associated unit label $m^{2}$
The meaningful precision of pore surface in the drilling context is typically: 1E-13 m²

Nouns.Name: TemperatureDrillingQuantity
Description: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance, indicating how hot or cold the substance is.
The SI unit for **temperature** is: kelvin with the associated unit label $K$
The meaningful precision of temperature in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 K

Nouns.Name: TemperatureGradientPerLengthDrillingQuantity
Description: A temperature gradient per lenth is the first derivative of a temperature compared to a distance: $\frac{dT}{ds}$, where $T$ is a temperature and $s$ is a distance.
The dimension of temperature gradient per length is:
The SI unit for **temperature gradient per length** is: kelvin per metre with the associated unit label $\frac{K}{m}$
The meaningful precision of temperature gradient per length in the drilling context is typically: 0.001 K/m

Nouns.Name: TensionDrillingQuantity
Description: Tension is the pulling or stretching force transmitted axially along an object such as a string, rope, chain, rod, truss member, or other object, so as to stretch or pull apart the object. In terms of force, it is the opposite of compression. Tension might also be described as the action-reaction pair of forces acting at each end of an object.
The meaningful precision of tension in the drilling context is typically: 100 N

Nouns.Name: ThermalConductivityDrillingQuantity
Description: Thermal conductivity is a material's ability to conduct heat. It measures how efficiently heat is transferred through a material when there is a temperature difference.
The dimension of thermal conductivity is:
The SI unit for **thermal conductivity** is: watt per metre kelvin with the associated unit label $\frac{W}{m \cdot K}$
The meaningful precision of thermal conductivity in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 W/m•K

Nouns.Name: ThermalConductivityGradientPerTemperatureDrillingQuantity
Description: A thermal conductivity gradient per temperature is the first derivative of a thermal conductivity compared to temperature: $\frac{dk}{dT}$, where $k$ is a thermal conductivity and $T$ is temperature.
The dimension of thermal conductivity gradient per temperature is:
The SI unit for **thermal conductivity gradient per temperature** is: watt per metre kelvin per kelvin with the associated unit label $\frac{(\frac{W}{(m \cdot K)}}{K}$
The meaningful precision of thermal conductivity gradient per temperature in the drilling context is typically: 0.01 (W/(m•K))/K

Nouns.Name: TorqueDrillingQuantity
Description: A torque is a measure of the rotational force applied to a body around an axis.
The SI unit for **torque** is: newton metre with the associated unit label $N \cdot m$
The meaningful precision of torque in the drilling context is typically: 0.1 N•m

Nouns.Name: TorqueGradientPerLengthDrillingQuantity
Description: A torque gradient per length is the first derivative of torque compared to a distance: $\frac{d\tau}{ds}$, where $\tau$ is a torque and $s$ is a distance.
The dimension of torque gradient per length is:
The SI unit for **torque gradient per length** is: newton metre per metre with the associated unit label $\frac{N \cdot m}{m}$
The meaningful precision of torque gradient per length in the drilling context is typically: 1 N•m/m

Nouns.Name: TorqueRateOfChangeDrillingQuantity
Description: A torque rate of change is the time derivative of a torque.
The dimension of torque rate of change is:
The SI unit for **torque** is: newton metre per second with the associated unit label $\frac{N \cdot m}{s}$
The meaningful precision of torque rate of change in the drilling context is typically: 0.1 N•m/s

Nouns.Name: VolumeDrillingQuantity
Description: A volume is the amount of three-dimensional space occupied by a body.
The SI unit for **volume** is: cubic metre with the associated unit label $m^{3}$
The meaningful precision of volume in the drilling context is typically: 0.0001 m³

Nouns.Name: VolumetricFlowrateDrillingQuantity
Description: A volumetric flowrate is the volume of fluid that passes per unit time: $\frac{dV}{dt}$, where $V$ is a volume and $t$ is time.
The dimension of volumetric flowrate is:
The SI unit for **volumetric flow rate** is: cubic metre per second with the associated unit label $\frac{m^{3}}{s}$
The meaningful precision of volumetric flowrate in the drilling context is typically: 0.0001 ft³/s

Nouns.Name: VolumetricFlowRateOfChangeDrillingQuantity
Description: A volumetric flow rate of change is the time derivative of a volumetric flowrate: $\frac{dQ}{dt}$, where $Q$ is a volumetric flowrate and $t$ is time.
The dimension of volumetric flow rate of change is:
The SI unit for **volumetric flow Rate rate of change** is: cubic metre per second squared with the associated unit label $\frac{m^{3}}{s^{2}}$
The meaningful precision of volumetric flow rate of change in the drilling context is typically: 1E-06 m³/s²

Nouns.Name: MomentOfInertiaDrillingQuantity
Description: The moment of inertia is is a measure of an object's resistance to changes in its rotation rate. It is the rotational analog of mass for linear motion. The moment of inertia depends on the mass distribution of an object and the axis of rotation.
The dimension of moment of inertia is:
The SI unit for **moment of inertia** is: kilogram metre squared with the associated unit label $kg \cdot m^{2}}$
The meaningful precision of the moment of inertia in the drilling context is typically: 1E-11 N

Nouns.Name: WeightOnBitDrillingQuantity
Description: A force is an influence that can cause an object to change its velocity unless counterbalanced by other forces.
The SI unit for **force** is: newton with the associated unit label $N$
The meaningful precision of weight on bit in the drilling context is typically: 100 N

Nouns.Name: MomentOfAreaDrillingQuantity
Description: A moment of area is a geometrical property of an area which reflects how its points are distributed with regard to an arbitrary axis. It is used in the study of beam bending and deflection in structural engineering.
The dimension of moment of area is:
The SI unit for **moment of area** is: metres to the fourth power with the associated unit label $m^{4}$
The meaningful precision of the moment of area in the drilling context is typically: 1E-16 N

Nouns.Name: DrillStemMechanicalModel
Description: A mechanical model for a drill-stem. Another standard name for drill-stem mechanical models is a torque and drag model.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffnessType
Description: A description of how the drill-stem stiffness is modelled.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalSoftModel
Description: An infinitively soft model assumes that the drill-stem deforms without any resistance when compressive loads are applied.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModel
Description: A stiff mechanical model considers that the drill-stem can deform laterally when put in compression.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModelAssumedContacts
Nouns.DisplayName: Mechanical stiff model with assumed contacts
Description: Such a stiff mechanical model presuposes the position of the contact points.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModelEstimatedContacts
Nouns.DisplayName: Mechanical stiff model with estimated contacts
Description: Such a stiff mechanical model estimates the position of the contact points.

Nouns.Name: TangencyLength
Description: the position along the drill-string, counted from the bit, from which we can consider that the pipes direction is tangential with the borehole direction.

Nouns.Name: TemporalBehaviorModel
Description: A classification of a model as a function of its temporal behavior.

Nouns.Name: SteadyStateModel
Description: A model for which the state variables do not change with time.

Nouns.Name: TransientModel
Description: A model for which the state variables changes with time.

Nouns.Name: ModelingApproach
Description: A classification of the modeling direction of a model.

Nouns.Name: ForwardModel
Description: For a forward model, the inputs are used to predict outputs.

Nouns.Name: InversionModel
Description: For an inversion model, the outputs are used to infer inputs or parameters.

Nouns.Name: HybridAnalysisModel
Description: A hybrid analysis model may combine forward and inverse steps in an iterative approach.

Nouns.Name: ModelingParadigm
Description: A classification of the relationship of the model to data or physical laws.

Nouns.Name: EmpiricalModel
Description: A model that heavily rely on data without using explicitly physical laws.

Nouns.Name: MechanisticModel
Description: A model that is based on first principles or physical laws.

Nouns.Name: PhysicsInformedDataDrivenModel
Description: A hybrid model that uses both physical laws and data.

Nouns.Name: MathematicalFormulation
Description: A classification of the mathematical formulation used by a model.

Nouns.Name: AlgebraicModel
Description: A model that uses algebraic equations.

Nouns.Name: OrdinaryDifferentialEquationModel
Description: A model that uses ordinary differential equations.

Nouns.Name: PartialDifferentialEquationModel
Description: A model that uses partial differential equations.

Nouns.Name: IntegralModel
Description: A model that uses integral equations.

Nouns.Name: ModelingObjective
Description: A classification of the objective/purpose of a model.

Nouns.Name: PredictiveModel
Description: A model that aims to forecast future behavior based on current data or conditions.

Nouns.Name: DescriptiveModel
Description: A model that seeks to explain or describe a system's behavior or underlying mechanisms.

Nouns.Name: CalibrationModel
Description: A model that focuses on adjusting parameters to improve alignment with observed data.

Nouns.Name: ControlModel
Description: A model that regulate or steer a system's behavior toward a desired outcome through inputs.

Nouns.Name: ModelScope
Description: A classification of a model with regards to its range of applicability.

Nouns.Name: GeneralModel
Description: A model with a broad range of application across various systems or phenomena.

Nouns.Name: SpecializedModel
Description: A model that is tailored to specific systems, scenarios or conditions.

Nouns.Name: ModelTransparency
Description: A classification of a model with regards to its transparency or interpretability.

Nouns.Name: BlackBoxModel
Description: The internal workings of the model are unknown or not interpretable, focusing only on the input-output relationship.

Nouns.Name: GrayBoxModel
Description: The model combines both data-drive and mechanistic models offering a partial transparency.

Nouns.Name: WhiteBoxModel
Description: The model is fully transparent and interpretable, with all internal mechanisms and assumptions clearly defined.

Nouns.Name: DataIntegrationStrategy
Description: A classification of a model with regards to its strategy for integrating data.

Nouns.Name: DataLevelIntegationModel
Description: A model that integrates data at a low-level like direct merging, using data transforms or filtering.

Nouns.Name: FeatureLevelIntegationModel
Description: A model that integrates data at a medium-level like using feature extraction and merging, reducing dimensionality,

Nouns.Name: DecisionLevelIntegationModel
Description: A model that integrates data at a high-level like using majority voting, ensemble methods, Bayesian decision fusion,

Nouns.Name: ModelledDegreeOfFreedom
Description: In physics and chemistry, a degree of freedom is an independent physical parameter in the formal description of the state of a physical system. A model may account for some or all of the degrees of freedom of the physical system.

Nouns.Name: AxialModelling
Description: The model accounts for the axial movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the axial velocity of fluid inside a pipe or an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the axial displacement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: RotationalModelling
Description: The model accounts for the rotational movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of pipe rotation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the rotational movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: LateralModelling
Description: The model accounts for the lateral movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the lateral pipe displacement on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the lateral  movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: RadialModelling
Description: The model accounts for the radial movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the radial pipe displacement on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the radial  movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: AngularLateralModelling
Description: The model accounts for the angular lateral movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe wobbling on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the wobbling of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: TangentialModelling
Description: The model accounts for the change of tangential direction of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: VerticalOndulationModelling
Description: The model accounts for the change of inclination of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe vertical ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the vertical ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: HorizontalOndulationModelling
Description: The model accounts for the change of azimuth of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe horizontal ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the horizontal ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: ModellingDimensions
Description: The number of dimensions that are accounted by the model

Nouns.Name: OneDModelling
Description: The model only accounts for one dimension
Examples: A hydraulic model only considers the axial direction for the flow in a pipe and in an annulus.

Nouns.Name: TwoDModelling
Description: The model only accounts for two dimensions
Examples: A hydraulic calculation considers the fluid velocity field in a cross-section but does not consider the axial direction. A heat transfer model considers the radial and axial heat transfer but assumes complete angular symmetry.

Nouns.Name: ThreeDModelling
Description: The model only accounts for three dimensions
Examples: A hydraulic calculation considers the fluid velocity field in a cross-section and in the axial direction. A heat transfer model considers the radial, angular and axial heat transfer.

Nouns.Name: ModellingDiscretization
Description: A characteristic of the discretization made by the model.

Nouns.Name: BoundaryDiscretization
Description: A model only considers the bounds of the physical system and does not apply any intermediate discretization.
Examples: The Kaasa model (https://doi.org/10.2118/143097-PA) is an example of hydraulic model that only accounts for the boundaries and does not utilize any intermediate discretization.

Nouns.Name: StrainWaveBasedDiscretization
Description: A model can properly estimate values at the level of strain wave propagation.
Examples: A transient mechanical model that is compatible with modelling acoustic waves in the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: MassTransferBasedDiscretization
Description: A model can properly estimate values at the level of mass transfer propagation.
Examples: A transient mechanical model that is compatible with modelling axial, rotationa and lateral drill-string displacement. A transient hydraulic model that is compatible with modelling fluid mass transfer inside the string and the annulus.

Nouns.Name: Location
Description: Physical location for a signal. Refers to: 1) a reference frame (via the HasReferenceFrame relation), that works as a system of coordinates 2) an origin (of type Location) via the HasReferenceFrameOrigin relation.

Nouns.Name: MeasurableQuantity
Description: Represents a quantity that allows meaningful comparisons.
A `MeasurableQuantity` is related to a Quantity using the `HasMeasurableQuantity` relation and its reciprocal
Context dependence: for example, Fluid density and Equivalent Circulating Density are represented
as two different "Measurable quantities", although they both refer to the same base SI quantities.
Typical sub-types of `MeasurableQuantity` are provided in MeasurableQuantityTypes. These types
can be used in a sort of singleton pattern, i.e., it is not necessary to create an individual to use them
in a relation. Also, if individuals are created with the same characteristics, they are considered as being
multiple representations of the same `Noun`. The list of `MeasurableQuantity` in MeasurableQuantityTypes is automatically generated
from the `PhysicalQuantities` defined in the Open Source Drilling Community ([OSDC](https://opensourcedrilling.org/)) project called `UnitConversion`
physical quantities for which a `MeaningfulPrecision` has beed defined are used to generate MeasurableQuantityTypes.
It is possible to look at all the physical quantities defined in the `OSDC UnitConversion` project by
using the web application hosted here: [`OSDC Physical Quantity Web App`](https://dev.digiwells.no/UnitConversion/webapp/PhysicalQuantity).

Nouns.Name: MeasurableQuantityUnitAssociation
Description: This `noun` is typically used to create an association between a `MeasurableQuantity`
and a `Unit` as for example when defining a `UnitSystem`.

Nouns.Name: Quantity
Description: A `Quantity` represents a physical quantity. A `Quantity` is characterized by its physical dimensions as defined in the SI

International System of units. There are typical sub-types of `Quantity` defined in `QuantityTypes`. These types can be used in a sort of singleton pattern, i.e., it is not necessary to create an individual to use them
in a relation. Also, if individuals are created with the same characteristics, they are considered as being
multiple representations of the same `Noun`. These typical
sub-types are automatically generated from the `PhysicalQuantities` defined in the Open Source Drilling
Only the physical quantities for which a `MeaningfulPrecision` is *not* defined are used to generate
QuantityTypes. It is possible to look at all the physical quantities defined in the `OSDC UnitConversion` project by
using the web application hosted here: [`OSDC Physical Quantity Web App`](https://dev.digiwells.no/UnitConversion/webapp/PhysicalQuantity).
Examples: Here is an example making use of a predifined quantity defined in `QuantityTypes`
And here is an example where the `Quantity` is defined from scratch:

Nouns.Name: Unit

NounAttributes.Name: Symbol
Description: a typical label for that unit.

NounAttributes.Name: ConversionFactorA
Description: Unit conversion from SI unit is performed as:

NounAttributes.Name: ConversionFactorB
Description: Unit conversion from SI unit is performed as:
Physical quantities, such as length, mass, time, temperature, and
electric current, are described using both a numerical value and a `Unit`. The `Unit` defines what
standard is being used to measure that quantity. A `Unit` is characterized by two attributes `ConversionFactorA`
and `ConversionFactorB` that are used to convert a SI value to the unit. Typical sub-types are made available. These types
can be used in a sort of singleton pattern, i.e., it is not necessary to create an individual to use them
in a relation. Also, if individuals are created with the same characteristics, they are considered as being
multiple representations of the same `Noun`. Typical sub-types for the Noun `Unit`
are defined in UnitTypes. These units are automatically generated from the unit conversions of each individual
`PhysicalQuantities` defined in the Open Source Drilling Community ([OSDC](https://opensourcedrilling.org/)) project called `UnitConversion`
It is possible to look at all the physical quantities defined in the `OSDC UnitConversion` project by
using the web application hosted here: [`OSDC Physical Quantity Web App`](https://dev.digiwells.no/UnitConversion/webapp/PhysicalQuantity).

Nouns.Name: UnitSystem
Description: A set of associations between measurable quantities and units.

Nouns.Name: AccelerationQuantity
Description: **Acceleration** is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. Velocity itself is the rate of change of displacement (or position) with respect to time. Therefore, acceleration is the rate of change of displacement twice with respect to time.
So, the dimension of velocity is **$[L T^{ -1}]$**.
3. **Acceleration** is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time:
Therefore, the dimension of acceleration is $[LT^{-2}]$.
The SI unit for **acceleration** is: metre per second squared with the associated unit label $\frac{m}{s^{2}}$

Nouns.Name: AmountSubstanceQuantity
Description: The **amount of substance** refers to the quantity of entities (such as atoms, molecules, ions, or other particles) in a system.The standard unit used to measure the amount of substance is the **mole** (mol). One mole corresponds to $6.022×10^{23}$ entities (Avogadro's number) of the given substance.

This is one of the nine fundamental dimensions in the International System of Units (SI).A fundamental quantity does not depend on any combinations of other fundamental dimensions.It is denoted $[N]$.
The SI unit for **amount substance** is: mole with the associated unit label $mol$

Nouns.Name: AngleGradientPerLengthQuantity
Description: Consider a situation where you have a length $L$ along which an angle $\theta$ changes. The angle variation gradient is defined as the **rate of change of the angle** per unit change in length. Mathematically, it can be expressed as:

Nouns.Name: AngleMagneticFluxDensityQuantity
Description: The **angle magnetic flux density** is the product of an angle by a magnetic flux density. Let's break it down step by step:

The **magnetic flux density** $\mathbf{B}$ is a measure of the strength and direction of the magnetic field at a particular point in space. Nouns.Name: AngularAccelerationQuantity
Description: An angular acceleration is the second derivative compared to time of a plan angle: $\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}$.
The dimension of angular acceleration is:
The SI unit for **angular acceleration** is: radian per second squared with the associated unit label $\frac{rad}{s^{2}}$

Nouns.Name: AngularVelocityQuantity
Description: An angular velocity is the first derivative compared to time of a plan angle: $\frac{d\theta}{dt}$.
The dimension of angular velocity is:
The SI unit for **angular velocity** is: radian per second with the associated unit label $\frac{rad}{s}$

Nouns.Name: AreaQuantity

The SI unit for **area** is: square metre with the associated unit label $m^{2}$

Nouns.Name: CompressibilityQuantity
Description: Compressibility is the measure of how much a substance's volume decreases under pressure. It indicates how easily a material or fluid can be compressed and is typically expressed as a change in volume per unit change in pressure.
The SI unit for **compressibility** is: inverse pascal with the associated unit label $\frac{1}{Pa}$

Nouns.Name: CurvatureQuantity
